questiontext.text: Suppose you want to predict future values of \(y_t\). Which of the following statements is correct?

generalfeedback.text:
1. True.
  2. False. You can!
  3. False. It’s a sliding window function
  4. False. It depends on data

answer.text: When working with weekly data adding \(L^7y_t\) as a regressor can improve forecast quality
You cannot make predictions for future values of \(y_t\) using linear regression model
An example of growing window function is mean of 2 previous values

feedback.text: False. It’s a sliding window function

answer.text: Averaging forecasts from random forest algorithm and ETS model will improve forecast quality

questiontext.text: Suppose you want to predict future values of monthly observations for China’s GDP \(y_t\) using the following set of regressors: seasonal lag, lag of a second difference, mean as a growing window and median as a sliding window of 3 values. What should the prediction sample 1 step ahead be?

generalfeedback.text:
1. NA
  2. NA
  3. NA
  4. Check lecture “Forecasting without a model”.

answer.text: \(\left(y_{T-11}, (y_T-y_{T-1}) - (y_{T-1}-y_{T-2}), \mathrm{Mean}\{y_{1},\,\cdot\cdot\cdot,\,y_{T}\}, \mathrm{Med}\{y_{T-2}, y_{T-1},\,y_{T}\}\right)\)
\(\left(y_{T-11}, (y_T-y_{T-1}) - (y_{T-1}-y_{T-2}), \mathrm{Mean}\{y_{T-2}, y_{T-1},\,y_{T}\}, \mathrm{Med}\{y_{1},\,\cdot\cdot\cdot,\,y_{T}\}\right)\)
\(\left(y_{T-12}, y_T-y_{T-1}, \mathrm{Mean}\{y_{1},\,\cdot\cdot\cdot,\,y_{T}\}, \mathrm{Med}\{y_{T-2}, y_{T-1},\,y_{T}\}\right)\)
\(\left(y_{T-12}, (y_T-y_{T-1}) - (y_{T-1}-y_{T-2}), \mathrm{Mean}\{y_{T-2}, y_{T-1},\,y_{T}\}, \mathrm{Med}\{y_{1},\,\cdot\cdot\cdot,\,y_{T}\}\right)\)

questiontext.text: Suppose you want to predict future values of \(y_t\). Which of the following statements is correct?

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. Box-Cox transformation will be useful if the variance of the time series monotonically changes over time
  2. True.
  3. False. It’s a trap!
  4. False. Decision trees are invariant under monotonic transformations of time

answer.text: If you suppose that the linear trend slows down over time you can apply Box-Cox transformation and use a linear trend as a regressor for the transformed data

feedback.text: False. Box-Cox transformation will be useful if the variance of the time series monotonically changes over time

answer.text: You can model yearly seasonality for daily data using fourier series
In a regression with a constant term you can add 7 dummies for each day of the week to model weekly seasonality
In gradient boosting, if you suppose that the linear trend slows down over time you should use square root of trend instead of linear trend

feedback.text: False. Decision trees are invariant under monotonic transformations of time

questiontext.text: Which of the following is regressors should be chosen for modelling yearly seasonality in daily data?

generalfeedback.text:
1. NA
  2. Check lecture “More predictors”.
  3. NA

answer.text: Both \(\operatorname{cos}\left({\frac{2\pi}{365}}\cdot\,t\right)\) and \(\operatorname{sin}\left({\frac{2\pi}{365}}\cdot\,t\right)\)
Either \(\operatorname{cos}\left({\frac{2\pi}{365}}\cdot\,t\right)\) or \(\operatorname{sin}\left({\frac{2\pi}{365}}\cdot\,t\right)\)
365 dummies for each day of the year

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements ARE correct?

generalfeedback.text:
1. True.
  2. False. You can use as many predictors as you like (unless you have enough data)
  3. False. In ARMAX regressors should be stationary
  4. True.

answer.text: In ARDL model lags of the predictors are used instead of noise lags \(u_t\)
In regression with ARMA errors you can use no more than two predictors

feedback.text: False. You can use as many predictors as you like (unless you have enough data)

answer.text: ARMAX can work with non-stationary predictors

feedback.text: False. In ARMAX regressors should be stationary

answer.text: ARDL model can be used if you want to find a long-term relationships between time series

questiontext.text:
Select all of the assumptions for ARMAX model

\[y_t = c + \gamma a_t + \beta_1 y_{t-1} + \ldots + \beta_p y_{t-p} + u_t + \alpha_1 u_{t-1} + \ldots + \alpha_q u_{t-q }\]

where \(a_t\) is a predictors and \((u_t)\) is white noise

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. \((y_t)\) and \((a_t)\) should be stationary
  2. False. \((y_t)\) and \((a_t)\) should be stationary
  3. True.
  4. True.
  5. True.
  6. True.

answer.text: Predictor \((a_t)\) is non-stationary, but \(\Delta(a_t)\) is stationary

feedback.text: False. \((y_t)\) and \((a_t)\) should be stationary

answer.text: Series \((y_t)\) is non-stationary

feedback.text: False. \((y_t)\) and \((a_t)\) should be stationary

answer.text: Predictor \((a_t)\) is stationary
\(E(a^4_t) < \infty\)
\(E(u_t \mid a_{t-1}, b_{t-1}, y_{t-1}, a_{t-2}, b_{t-2}, y_{t-2} , \ldots) = 0\)
Series \((y_t)\) is stationary

questiontext.text:
Consider gas dataset. You need to estimate a linear regression model for the logarithm of gas series staring from 1970. Use square root of the trend as a regressor. Provide the forecast 10 steps ahead for the log(gas) rounded up to 3 decimal digits as an answer.

You can load the gas dataset in R by importing forecast library or if you use other programming languages you can download it here.

generalfeedback.text: You can use lm() and predict() functions.

questiontext.text:
Consider LakeHuron dataset. You need to estimate a linear regression model with two regressors: sliding window for mean applied to 2 previous values and growing window for mean. Provide the R squared for the estimated model as an answer with 3 decimal digits.

You can load the LakeHuron data set in R by issuing the following command at the console data(“LakeHuron”) or if you use other programming languages you can download it here.

generalfeedback.text: You can use cummean() and lag() functions to create regressors.
